subject: RE: [EVP-ITC] Re: introducing myself
author: bruce halliday
full_text:
--_af06f780-5a41-4bda-8680-ccc26b8ea430_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Frank,
 
I think it would be better if whatever amount of tones where being=
 used, 
instead of in sequence they where combined to make one harmonic ton=
e 
then the entity that was forming the words could manipulate the various =
tones in the 
signal and to us it would sound like one smooth continuous vo=
ice. just an idea.
 
Bruce

Bruce Halliday Paranormal Investigating Team 

=

To: evp-itc@yahoogroups.comFrom: franks-boxes@...: Mon, 3 Dec =
2007 07:50:26 -0700Subject: RE: [EVP-ITC] Re: introducing myself




Thanks=
. Spiricom did use 13 tone generators as away of produce something like tha=
t raw audio. Then transmitted the tones a short distance so they could modu=
lated by the spirits. What I think we've found is you don't have to transmi=
t raw audio, the entities can manipuilate it in the electronics, it would s=
eem. These days you can make four tone generators on a chip much smaller th=
en a dime. So you could have multiple tones in a small space, then with new=
er digital switching techniques, combine the tones in a way that would simi=
late speech bits. The goal as with all of this stuff is clear communcation.=
 I think it is way too soon, and not enough work has been done for anyone t=
o try to create theory of how this stuff work.   I used radio becasue it's =
a convienient source of raw audio, but becasue of noise, and the variations=
 in the number of stations in different areas, it makes it an unreliable me=
thod. It works great here in Denver, it's not so good up in Cheyenne, Wyo, =
or Grand Junction, Co.    Frank-S


To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.comFrom: overun=
der21@...: Mon, 3 Dec 2007 07:20:14 +0000Subject: [EVP-ITC] Re: i=
ntroducing myself


I have read about tone generators myself but that seems=
 to be almost a step backward. Wasn't spiricom in essence a oscillioscope/t=
one generator? I know it was considered for a while to be the most successf=
ul, but it was very electronic or synthetic in sound and required quite an =
operational budget and space.I think with your invention we have reached th=
e cusp of being able to create the walkman of EVP/ITC - we're almost there.=
 And with the discovery of the Radioshack mod and the experience we and oth=
ers have had since your box first debuted I think we're almost to the point=
 where it will be very inexpensive to make a reliable box and/or something =
that the average person could make following instructions.Of course the hol=
y grail is something that reliably generates clear voices every time with l=
ittle or no white noise. I know I read that someone was trying to create a =
device that did that, created the white noise and then cancelled it out, ho=
pefully leaving you with just the voice.Oh, and a reliable television ITC d=
evice would be quite the find too. I plan on creating a RS mod box that wil=
l be self contained and portable...and my thought was if it works reliably =
I wonder if I could integrate a simply video ITC generator into it as well.=
 It would be great to be able to capture both audio and video.Anyways, carr=
y on Frank. I know you're doing good work. IF you search the internet for E=
VP and especially ghost box recordings your name is constantly popping up i=
n the recordings, so I'm guessing those communicating with us are quite hap=
py with you.How does it feel to be the first known living person to be a ce=
lebrity on the other side, lol?--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Frank Sumpti=
on <franks-boxes@...> wrote:>> > Yeah, I do seem to get answers to question=
 with my Ghostman box (one of a kind Mini box). the Ghostman is a combinati=
n of the linear sweep and an AM/FM radio with direct out put, no sound cham=
ber or mics. I have kinda palyed wiht white noise, but not for about six ye=
ars. There's some ideas about using tone generators instead of radio. > > F=
rank-S> > > > > To: EVP-ITC@...: overunder21@...: Sun, 2 Dec 2007 13:50:23 =
+0000Subject: [EVP-ITC] introducing myself> > > > > Not really new to the g=
roup, been lurking for a few months just reading, listening, and studying.U=
nfortunately I'm not much of an engineer so I've been picking up books to h=
elp me better understand the technical side of the boxes. I understand the =
practicality of them (ie- creating random white noise to allow EVPs to be f=
ormed) but I hope to gain an understanding of how they work technically in =
hopes of building and tweaking my own.For me EVP has been something I've be=
en into all my life without knowing what it was (I'm 30 now, I first learne=
d the technical term about 22 or 23) - I guess I'm what people would call '=
sensitive' or whatever. But besides that, early on I was fascinated by seem=
ingly coherant sounds that would come out of random noise on my clock radio=
 in my bedroom as a kid, from what sounded like voices (thought I was crazy=
 for a while) to even morse code - for a long time one of my radios would p=
roduce random clicks or pops even when the speaker was off. My dad jokingly=
 suggested it was morse code, so I studied morse code and discovered that a=
t least some of it could be morse letters...usually they would spell one wo=
rd and then gibberish.Anyways, once I learned what EVP was I began messing =
around with recorders etc. My first clear recording came from using EVP mak=
er and was someone saying 'we have been waiting for you.' A few days later,=
 after a frustrating lack of communication they just told me 'build a box.(=
this happened to be after I learned of frank.)' I've been looking at all th=
e boxes and their positives and negatives and this is what I'm seeing:Frank=
s models seem to produce the most consistant results but also seem to be le=
ss two way than some others (ie Joe's Box.) Joe's Box and the new radio sha=
ck mod seem to have some very clear voices coming through but skeptics can =
argue that all you are hearing is snippets from radio broadcasts.My thought=
 for a cost-effective, low-tech alternative is to combine the two in that y=
ou create a radio shack mod like the UFOGeek one (multiple radios, a mixer,=
 etc) and run it through an echo box.Personally I believe that analog is gi=
ving the best results overall, and I think it has to do with ease of manipu=
lating the signal. Therefore my thought is taking a digital white noise sig=
nal like that produced by the radio shack mods and then essentially broadca=
sting it into the echo chamber and having a mic pick it up gives you the an=
alog aspect.My question is has anyone tried this? And I was hoping for thou=
ghts on the pros and cons of using AM vs. FM or both.Oh, one other thing- a=
ny programmers/engineers out there? Someone that could write code to allow =
us to randomly band scan a digital radio? > > > > > > > ___________________=
_______________________________________> Share life as it happens with the =
new Windows Live.Download today it's FREE!> http://www.windowslive.com/shar=
e.html?ocid=3DTXT_TAGLM_Wave2_sharelife_112007>

You keep typing, we keep g=
iving. Download Messenger and join the i=92m Initiative now. Join in!

I think it would be better if whatever amo=
unt of tones where being used, <BR>
instead of in sequence they where combi=
ned to make one harmonic tone <BR>
then the entity that was forming the wor=
ds could manipulate the various tones in the <BR>
signal and to us it would=
 sound like one smooth continuous voice. just an idea.<BR>
 <BR>
Bruce=
